de.polygonal.ds.BitVector

type
class
A bit-vector is meant to condense separate bit values into an array as close as possible so that no space is wasted.

Constructor

new(x : Int)
Creates a bit-vector with an initial size of x bits.

Instance Methods

bucketSize() : Int

The total number of integers used for storing the bits.

capacity() : Int

The exact maximum number of bits that the bit-vector can store.

clone() : BitVector

Duplicates the bit-vector.

clr(i : Int) : Void

throws
de.polygonal.core.util.AssertionError index out of range (if debug flag is set).
Sets the bit at index i to 0.

clrAll() : Void

Sets all bits in the bit-vector to 0.

has(i : Int) : Bool

throws
de.polygonal.core.util.AssertionError Index out of range (if debug flag is set).
Returns true if the bit at index i is 1.

ofBytes(bytes : haxe.io.BytesData, ?bigEndian : Bool) : Void

parameters
The byte order (default is little endian)
throws
de.polygonal.core.util.AssertionError input is null (if debug flag is set).
Copies the bits from bytes into this bit vector. The bit-vector is resized to the size of the specified byte array.

resize(x : Int) : Void

Resizes the bit-vector to x bits. Existing values are preserved.

set(i : Int) : Void

throws
de.polygonal.core.util.AssertionError Index out of range (if debug flag is set).
Sets the bit at index i to 1.

setAll() : Void

Sets all bits in the bit-vector to 1.

size() : Int

The total number of bits set.

toBytes(?bigEndian : Bool) : haxe.io.BytesData

parameters
The byte order (default is little endian)
Converts the bit-vector to a byte array. The number of bytes equals bucketSize() * 4 and the number of written bits equals capacity().

toString() : String

Returns a string representing the current object. Prints out all elements if compiled with the -debug flag.
Example: 
	  var bv = new BitVector(40);
	  for (i in 0...bv.capacity())
	  {
	    if (i & 1 == 0)
	    bv.set(i);
	  }
	  trace(bv); //output:

	  {BitVector, set/all: 20/40}
	  |<
	    0 -> b01010101010101010101010101010101
	    1 -> b00000000000000000000000001010101
	  >|
